quoteLast: , are on delivery in the private box renters' office at about 12.30 p.m. The postmen start out with the letters at 1.10 p.m. As the hour of posting for the outward Continental night mails is 2.10 p.m., it is only the private box renters who have time, brief though it be, to reply to their correspondence on the day of receiving it.
title: The Bristol Royal Mail: Post, Telegraph, and Telephone
author: Tombs, Robert Charles, 1842-1923

quoteFirst: Then I shook in my glee. Someone had pushed on the hands of the clock, and it was
quoteLast: . There was a rustle of excitement in the room. The silence of expectancy followed. "Two-minutes-to" narrowed into "One-minute-to"; and after a premonitory click, which produced sufficient excitement to interfere with our breath, the clock struck twelve.
title: Tell England: A Study in a Generation
author: Raymond, Ernest, 1888-1974

quoteFirst: Then came the breakfast,--that dullest, saddest hour of all. To feed heavily
quoteLast: is always a nuisance,--a nuisance so abominable that it should be avoided under any other circumstances than a wedding in your own family. But that wedding-breakfast, when it does come, is the worst of all feeding.

quoteFirst: On the evening of the 31st December the members of the club muster in force at their snug quarters in Twenty-fourth Street. At two or
quoteLast: all the lights are put out, and "Auld lang syne" is sung in chorus, to bid good-bye to the year that is passing away. As soon as the clock has struck the midnight hour[5], the lights are relit, all the company strike up "He's a jolly good fellow," and there is a general hand-shaking and wishing of good wishes for the coming year.
title: Jonathan and His Continent: Rambles Through American Society
author: O'Rell, Max, 1848-1903; Allyn, Jack; Blouët, Mary Bartlett [Translator]
